notes:
1. Definition

A wall footing, also known as a strip footing, is a continuous strip of concrete that serves to spread the weight of a load-bearing wall over a larger area of soil. It is a type of shallow foundation.

2. Purpose and Use

Wall footings are used to support linear loads from foundation walls, retaining walls, or load-bearing architectural walls. The continuous nature of the footing ensures that the load is distributed evenly along the length of the wall.

3. Design

The primary design consideration for a wall footing is its width ($B$). The width must be sufficient to ensure that the bearing pressure exerted on the soil does not exceed the allowable soil bearing capacity ($q_{allow}$).

The analysis is typically done per unit length of the wall (e.g., per foot or per meter). The bearing pressure ($q$) is calculated as:

$$ q = \frac{P}{B} $$

Where $P$ is the load from the wall per unit length (e.g., in lb/ft or kN/m). The required width is then:

$$ B_{req} \ge \frac{P}{q_{allow}} $$
